photo.description: It was originally surmounted by the bronze horses of Saint Mark's Cathedral in Venice, captured by Napoleon, but these were returned there in 1815. They were replaced by a quadriga sculpted by François Joseph Bosio, depicting Peace riding in a triumphal chariot, led by gilded Victories on either side. photo.description: Designed by Charles Percier and Pierre Léonard Fontaine and built between 1806-1808 by the Emperor Napoleon I on the model of the Arch of Septimius Severus in Rome to commemorate France's military victories in 1805. Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arc_de_Triomphe_du_Carrousel

photo.title: Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel, Paris

photo.description: The Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel, located on the Place du Carrousel to the west of the Musée du Louvre, is a triumphal arch commemorating France's military victories in 1805. Designed by Charles Percier and Pierre Léonard Fontatine, the arch was made between 1806-1808 by the Emperor Napoleon I on the model of the Arch of Septimius Severus in Rome to front the Palace de Tuileries. The arch, which stands at 63 feet high, 75 feet wide, and 24 feet deep, is actually composed of three arches--the larger arch, standing at 21 feet high and 9 feet wide, is flanked by two smaller arches, each 14 feet, 16 inches high and 9 feet wide. It was originally surmounted by Horses of Saint Mark, which Napoleon seized from Saint Mark's Episcopal Cathedral in Venice in 1797. The Horses were returned in 1815, and replaced by a quadriga sculpted by Baron François Joseph Bosio, depicting Peace riding in a triumphal chariot led by gilded Victories on both sides. The composition commemorates the Restoration of the Bourbons following Napoleon's downfall. Around its exterior are eight Corinthian columns of granite, topped by eight soldiers of the Empire designed by Pierre-Charles Bridan, Charles Louis Corbet and Robert Guillaume Dardel. In between the columns, rose marble bas-reliefs commemorate Napoleon's diplomatic and military victories--Jean-Joseph Espercieux' Battle of Austerlitz, Etienne Jules Ramey's Tilsit Conference, Louis Pierre Deseine's Napoleon Entering Vienna, Pierre Cartellier's Surrender of Ulm, Clodion's Napoleon Entering Munich, and Jacques Philippe Lesueur's Peace of Pressburg. In the attic between the soldiers, bas-reliefs depict the Arms of the Kingdom of Italy with figures representing History and the Arts; the Arms of the French Empire with Victory, Fame, History and Abundance; and Wisdom and Strength holding the arms of the Kingdom of Italy, accompanied by Prudence and Victory.
photo.tags: muséedulouvre arcdetriomphedecarrousel france europe louvre museum musee musée arc arch museedulouvre arcdetriomphe louvremuseum sculpture jardinducarrousel paris placeducarrousel charlespercier pierreléonardfontatine pierreleonardfontatine triumphalarch quadriga baronfrançoisjosephbosio

photo.title: Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel

photo.description: The Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel is a monument dating from 1809 built under Napoleon Bonaparte. Built in honor of the Grand Army of Napoleon Bonaparte between 1807 and 1809, the monument is located in front of the Louvre, on the esplanade before the Tuileries. It celebrates the victory of the French army at Austerlitz. L'armée française embarquée à Boulogne menaçait l'Angleterre Une troisième coalition éclate sur le continent Les Français volent de l'océan au Danube La Bavière est délivrée, l'armée autrichienne prisonnière à Ulm Napoléon entre dans Vienne, il triomphe à Austerlitz En moins de cent jours, la coalition est dissoute El ejército francés se embarcó en Boulogne amenazando Inglaterra Se rompe la tercera coalición en el continente Los franceses vuelandel océano en Danubio Bavaria es emitido, el ejército austriaco en Ulm prisionero Napoleón entró en Viena, triunfa en Austerlitz En menos de cien días, la coalición se disuelve The French army embarked at Boulogne threatened England A third coalition breaks on the continent The French fly the ocean in Danube Bavaria is issued, the Austrian army at Ulm prisoner Napoleon entered Vienna, he triumphs at Austerlitz In less than one hundred days, the coalition is dissolved GPS geotags: Avenue du Général Lemonier, 1er Arrondissement, Paris, France No crop Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mark II Lens: Zeiss Makro-Planar T* 2/100 ZE Focal Length: 100 mm Exposure: ¹⁄₁₀ sec at f/5.6 ISO: 100

photo.description: Napoléon at the Tuileries The creation of rue de Rivoli in 1801 entails the demolition of the Capuchin and Feuillant monasteries. The first arcaded town house is built in 1806. Napoléon revives the royal plan to join the Louvre and Tuileries palaces, and creates a thoroughfare on the site of the future Carrousel triumphal arch. Spectacular temporary buildings are erected for his wedding to Marie-Louise, including a portico, a triumphal arch, and a grandstand: festivals and celebrations return to the gardens.

photo.description: The Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel, located on the Place du Carrousel to the west of the Musée du Louvre, is a triumphal arch commemorating France's military victories in 1805. Designed by Charles Percier and Pierre Léonard Fontatine, the arch was made between 1806-1808 by the Emperor Napoleon I on the model of the Arch of Septimius Severus in Rome to front the Palace de Tuileries. The arch, which stands at 63 feet high, 75 feet wide, and 24 feet deep, is actually composed of three arches--the larger arch, standing at 21 feet high and 9 feet wide, is flanked by two smaller arches, each 14 feet, 16 inches high and 9 feet wide. It was originally surmounted by Horses of Saint Mark, which Napoleon seized from Saint Mark's Episcopal Cathedral in Venice in 1797. The Horses were returned in 1815, and replaced by a quadriga sculpted by Baron François Joseph Bosio, depicting Peace riding in a triumphal chariot led by gilded Victories on both sides. The composition commemorates the Restoration of the Bourbons following Napoleon's downfall. Around its exterior are eight Corinthian columns of granite, topped by eight soldiers of the Empire designed by Pierre-Charles Bridan, Charles Louis Corbet and Robert Guillaume Dardel. In between the columns, rose marble bas-reliefs commemorate Napoleon's diplomatic and military victories--Jean-Joseph Espercieux' Battle of Austerlitz, Etienne Jules Ramey's Tilsit Conference, Louis Pierre Deseine's Napoleon Entering Vienna, Pierre Cartellier's Surrender of Ulm, Clodion's Napoleon Entering Munich, and Jacques Philippe Lesueur's Peace of Pressburg. In the attic between the soldiers, bas-reliefs depict the Arms of the Kingdom of Italy with figures representing History and the Arts; the Arms of the French Empire with Victory, Fame, History and Abundance; and Wisdom and Strength holding the arms of the Kingdom of Italy, accompanied by Prudence and Victory.

photo.description: The Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel, located on the Place du Carrousel to the west of the Musée du Louvre, is a triumphal arch commemorating France's military victories in 1805. Designed by Charles Percier and Pierre Léonard Fontatine, the arch was made between 1806-1808 by the Emperor Napoleon I on the model of the Arch of Septimius Severus in Rome to front the Palace de Tuileries. The arch, which stands at 63 feet high, 75 feet wide, and 24 feet deep, is actually composed of three arches--the larger arch, standing at 21 feet high and 9 feet wide, is flanked by two smaller arches, each 14 feet, 16 inches high and 9 feet wide. It was originally surmounted by Horses of Saint Mark, which Napoleon seized from Saint Mark's Episcopal Cathedral in Venice in 1797. The Horses were returned in 1815, and replaced by a quadriga sculpted by Baron François Joseph Bosio, depicting Peace riding in a triumphal chariot led by gilded Victories on both sides. The composition commemorates the Restoration of the Bourbons following Napoleon's downfall. Around its exterior are eight Corinthian columns of granite, topped by eight soldiers of the Empire designed by Pierre-Charles Bridan, Charles Louis Corbet and Robert Guillaume Dardel. In between the columns, rose marble bas-reliefs commemorate Napoleon's diplomatic and military victories--Jean-Joseph Espercieux' Battle of Austerlitz, Etienne Jules Ramey's Tilsit Conference, Louis Pierre Deseine's Napoleon Entering Vienna, Pierre Cartellier's Surrender of Ulm, Clodion's Napoleon Entering Munich, and Jacques Philippe Lesueur's Peace of Pressburg. In the attic between the soldiers, bas-reliefs depict the Arms of the Kingdom of Italy with figures representing History and the Arts; the Arms of the French Empire with Victory, Fame, History and Abundance; and Wisdom and Strength holding the arms of the Kingdom of Italy, accompanied by Prudence and Victory.
photo.tags: muséedulouvre arcdetriomphedecarrousel france europe louvre museum musee musée arc arch museedulouvre arcdetriomphe louvremuseum basrelief relief surrenderofulm pierrecartellier sculpture jardinducarrousel paris placeducarrousel charlespercier pierreléonardfontatine pierreleonardfontatine triumphalarch
photo.title: Paris - Musée du Louvre: Arc de Triomphe de Carrousel - Surrender of Ulm

It was originally surmounted by Horses of Saint Mark, which Napoleon seized from Saint Mark's Episcopal Cathedral in Venice in 1797. photo.tags: triumphal arch france paris
photo.title: Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel

photo.description: So, the last evening in Paris I went to take some night shots of the Louvre and Seine. I'd just been taking a shot of the Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel, and picked up the tripod to move around to another angle, when all of a sudden these tourists started flowing under the arch in all its floodlit glory on these segway machines. It was all a bit slo-mo and requiring of Chariots of Fire theme music, and it wouldn't have been entirely out of place in a Monty Python sketch. I wish I'd left the camera where it was for an extra minute, then I could have got a photograph of them coming through the arch. Fortunately they remained in front of the Louvre for a good while, so I could take a photo of them then. I just thought they looked so spectacular and ludicrous.
photo.tags: paris night light louvre tourists silly segway twtmesh040809 lpagain
photo.title: seguing 'round town

photo.title: Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel

photo.description: The Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel is a monument dating from 1809 built under Napoleon Bonaparte. Built in honor of the Grand Army of Napoleon Bonaparte between 1807 and 1809, the monument is located in front of the Louvre, on the esplanade before the Tuileries. It celebrates the victory of the French army at Austerlitz. GPS geotags: Avenue du Général Lemonier, 1er Arrondissement, Paris, France Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mark II Lens: Zeiss Distagon T* 2/25 ZE Focal Length: 25 mm Exposure: ⅕ sec at f/6.3 ISO: 100

photo.title: Arc de triomphe du Carrousel | 120914-9869-jikatu

photo.description: The Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel is a triumphal arch in Paris, located in the Place du Carrousel on the site of the former Tuileries Palace. It was built between 1806 and 1808 to commemorate Napoleon's military victories of the previous year. The more famous Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile nearby was designed in the same year, but it took thirty years to build, and it is about twice as massive. Ref: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arc_de_Triomphe_du_Carrousel À la voix du vainqueur d’Austerlitz L’empire d’Allemagne tombe La confédération du Rhin commence Les royaumes de Bavière et de Wurtemberg sont créés Venise est réunie à la couronne de fer L’Italie entière se range sous les lois de son libérateur A la voz del vencedor de Austerlitz El imperio alemán cae La Confederación del Rin comienza Los reinos de Baviera y Württemberg se crean Venecia se reunió en la corona de hierro El conjunto de Italia se amolda a las leyes de su libertador At the voice of the victor of Austerlitz The German Empire falls The Confederation of the Rhine begins The kingdoms of Bavaria and Württemberg are created Venice is held in the iron crown The whole of Italy ranks under the laws of his deliverer Avenue du Général Lemonier, 1er Arrondissement, Paris, Paris, France Camera: Canon EOS 5D Mark II Lens: Zeiss Makro-Planar T* 2/100 ZE Focal Length: 100 mm Exposure: ¹⁄₁₆₀ sec at f/4.0 ISO: 100

photo.description: PARIGI - La piramide vetrata all'ingresso del Louvre. Una volta nella vita si può fotografare. Questa, di volta, è particolare, perché probabilmente la colorazione del tramonto è dovuta alle ceneri del vulcano islandese Eyjafjallajökull, portate dai venti verso l'Est europeo. on black Per il nome del vulcano, ovviamente ho fatto copia/incolla
